reporting-org.narrative: The federal government of the United States

title.narrative: Technical Assistance for Banking & Financial Services - Guinea

description.narrative: Support the establishment of a sound private, well-functioning, equitable financial sector that fulfills critical roles in a market economy, most importantly financial intermediation – the efficient generation and allocation of savings to their most productive use.

This award strives to support the establishment of a sound private, well-functioning, equitable financial sector that fulfills critical roles in a market economy. More specifically, this includes The Banking team advisors are providing intermittent technical assistance to the Central Bank in the following areas: Assisting with the implementation phase of Guineas National Strategy for Financial Inclusion; Providing assistance with the development of a comprehensive e-money issuer (EMI) regulatory framework, including improving the current EMI regulation, developing licensing guidelines, and implementing supervisory policies and procedures; Designing an automated reporting framework for the collection and analysis of data from non-bank financial institutions, including EMIs and microfinance institutions; Assisting the BCRG with the further modernization of the payments system to allow for and interoperability among banks as well as greater participation by non-bank financial institutions;Assisting the BCRG with strengthening supervision of the microfinance sector; and Enabling MSMEs access to credit by: Drafting and adopting new laws for Secured Transactions, Factoring, and Leasing. Designing, Creating, and Launching a Registry of Moveable Assets.

participating-org.narrative: The federal government of the United States

owner-org.narrative: The federal government of the United States

description.narrative: The Ebola Virus Disease outbreak of 2014 - 2015 significantly affected the advances that Guinea has made since democracy took root in 2010. Though the epidemic was largely brought under control late by 2015, Guinea will continue to face the social, economic, and health consequences of the Ebola outbreak. The Ebola outbreak highlighted the weak governance that has crippled the well-being and growth of the country for decades. Dysfunctional government administration, pervasive public corruption, and rampant infectious diseases exacerbated by malnutrition are among Guinea's challenges. Environmental sanitation is poor, cholera and typhoid epidemics occur regularly, along with pervasive malaria and diarrhea that kill many, especially children. U.S. assistance will increase the availability of quality health services and improve food security, with a particular focus on improving delivery of health services, strengthening health systems, and encouraging communities to access health services. Assistance will also target civil society, media programming, and strategic security sector reform to encourage the development of a rule of law culture in Guinea, which is critical to reshaping the country's institutions. The United States seeks to accomplish these objectives through effective collaboration with the Government of Guinea (GOG), other donors, local non-governmental organizations (NGOs) and the private sector.
